subject: RE: [junit] Server Side EJB application testing

messageBody:
Gowri,

My current approach to testing any of our J2EE work is to not test any
Entity, Session or Message-Driven Beans. I have faith in Entity Beans,
hence I do not test them at all. For Session and Message-Driven Beans, I
code these to rely on a number of collaborating classes. In other words,
these beans contain code that simply directs the interaction of other
classes. Since these other classes are not beans, test fixture for them is
easy to set up and tear down, and I test them. For example, I might have a
Message-Driven Bean that gives its received message to a class that parses
the message. The result of parsing might then be handed to another class
(or classes) that does (that do) some work. Finally, the result of such
work would be passed to a communicator class that knows where the results
need to go and how to send them there.

In brief, I've found that the design of our J2EE work is greatly improved
with this approach. For any of our existing code that isn't written this
way, I try to push it in that direction with each refactoring session.

I hope that this approach offers some insight or a point of view not yet
considered.

Best wishes,
Craig

> I need to test a server side EJB application with JUnit. How
> would I accomplish this. Our application follows a J2EE,
> session façade, architecture with EJB's that reflect database
> table rows. Other classes in the application support the
> functionality of the application. My particular problem is
> that I have to ensure that the errors being thrown by my
> applications are logical. Are there tests I can write to
> accomplish this? Examples if any are appreciated. Thanks in
> advance for your input.
